The fact that you can't perfectly represent pi in binary has nothing to do with the fact that the universe can't encode a response in the digits of pi.

"Any computer representation will always have a minimum, definable error" = L/2 where L is equal to the value of the LSB. Actually, for any particular representation, the error might be less, but at most all you can say for any arbitrary estimate, E, is that the actual value is between E+L/2 and E-L/2.

I made no comment in regard to any hypothetical alternate universe.

It will always have an error, but there's no minimum error. Every additional bit cuts the error in half. Furthermore, this error is something mathematical. It's not going to be different in a different universe.

I agree.  We have completely different definitions of faith.  Even if you already have religious learning or experience, as a skeptic, I would hope that you are willing to admit that you understand of faith might be incomplete and needing further investigation and more experience.  Faith is a much more profound process (for many, not all) than what you have defined.  Belief is based merely upon facts or feelings while faith is more personal and tested on a deeper level and is refined by doubts.

One definition of faith is believing something for which there is no empirical evidence. Which, by definition, is the opposite of reserving judgement until enough evidence exists to support belief.

Your alien race example makes 100% perfect sense to a skeptic. I would reserve judgement until enough evidence is presented. I would not have "faith" that humans are peaceful.

But I believe our "argument" is more over semantics than substance. I think you define faith differently than I do.

While you make sense, I do not agree with your definitions or conclusions at all. Skepticism, by definition, is assuming a position of doubt.

You need to read up on what a false dichotomy is again. My statement does NOT say you are either a skeptic or have faith. You can claim to be a "skeptic" with faith, but the two terms are in direct opposition to each other - from a purely academic perspective - so you must make some concessions to claim both (ie your definitions of both are not typical).

You propose a false dichotomy of faith versus skepticism because you hold the belief that everything can be analyzed.  Some phenomena or truths are beyond our ability to fully ascertain truth.  Furthermore, faith is not merely a cerebral act.  Faith is more of a choice of how to live one's life.  It is deeper than merely being a thought.

True faith, like true love, often must be tested to be developed.  So faith is not the opposite of skepticism because it allows for doubt.

(continued)

Alien races, one war-like, one peaceful, visit the Earth in the future.  They find a fossilized human skeleton with a screwdriver sticking out of the skull.  The war-like aliens assume they've found evidence of crude human weaponry.  The peaceful aliens insist that this was an accident with a tool not meant for combat.

They really don't know (yet) how the screw-driver got there.

And, repetition of such findings may or may not change their preconceptions.

Not quite. A hypothesis is an educated guess and the starting part of the scientific method. A theory is a well-supported explanation of a phenomena, while a law is a description of a phenomena. A theory may be more, equally, or less well-supported than a law, because they serve different purposes. Laws are more like (and, in fact, can be) mathematical equations. For instance, Newton's 2nd law is, essentially, F=ma. Theories can't be summed up so easily. Neither is "better" than the other.

In science, a theory is something that's as proven as possible within the realm of our current understanding/ability. It may (almost certainly will) be refined in the future, as we learn more, but it's uncommon for theories to be proven totally wrong (note that the examples you can think of that have were more assumptions than proper, tested theories). We actually HAVE observed evolution in a laboratory setting, in bacteria and fruit flies, and there's tons of evidence supporting it.

Three very complicated, but cooperating capabilities had to come together at once in the giraffe.

The Giraffe also by itself utterly disproves Evolution.

The brain has a sponge-like material just behind the brain that has gradually been absorbing blood all the time the giraffe has been drinking. When the giraffe suddenly raises his head, that blood very slowly drains out of the brain, thus keeping the giraffe from passing out, while the spigots open up and the blood begins to flow naturally.

However, when the giraffe abruptly raises its head after drinking, the blood would flow so rapidly downward through the force of gravity that the animal would suffer a sudden loss of blood to the brain, thus causing him to pass out cold. However, God has built a third capability that prevents this from occurring.

However, when the giraffe lowers its neck to drink, the blood that is circulating in its neck will suddenly come rushing down by the force of gravity. This sudden rush of blood is so strong, it would quickly cause the giraffe to suffer a brain aneurysm, killing the animal instantly. Therefore, the second capability is that spigots are built into his neck arteries that instantly close down whenever the animal lowers its neck to drink water.

Giraffes defy evolution because the neck of the Giraffe extends so high into the air, the heart must contain an extraordinarily strong pump to force the blood from the lower body to the highest reaches of the brain. Thus, the first capability unique to the giraffe is a heart that is also a most powerful pump.

Gene duplication: no new information.
Frame shift: completely different information.
Gene duplication plus frame shift: added information.
It's really simple. You have one protein's genetic code. That gets duplicated so the protein is not lost. One of the two undergoes a frame shift and makes a new protein. If the new protein doesn't do more harm than good, it has a good chance of getting through the process of natural selection and a new functional protein has then arisen unintelligently.

Gene duplication- More of the same genetic information, not new information
Frame shift- Yet another random mutation.
Neither of those explains how new functional proteins can form. As a clarification, by information I mean DNA that codes for something unique. Duplicates are not information and random noise is not information.
"If not natural, then, supernatural?" Indeed. The only way that vast amounts of information can be created is through intelligence.

I consider micro evolution to be focused on individual creatures, and it is any change of DNA. I consider macro to be focused on a population, and it is when two creatures of a species can no longer inter breed due to evolution.

There is a small chance of it happening, but I think you're exaggerating the chance greatly. The creatures that would have developed something like that would have had a very high reproduction rate, and a short lifespan. This also would take place over hundreds of thousands of years. I understand that mutations are random, but what you seem to not understand is that evolution happens to a population, not an individual.

"If one of these creatures were to mutate, and have a very small light sensitive patch of skin"- That's a big "if". In fact, that's a gigantic "if". You see, random mutations are just that--random. We're talking number of atoms in the universe here.

(cont.) Let's say there is an ecosystem that has creatures that have no eyes. If one of these creatures were to mutate, and have a very small light sensitive patch of skin, he would have a higher chance of survival. Even if all this light patch does is let the creature know when it is light, and when it is dark. This would let the creature know when there are quick changes in light, which show when another creature is close. This would be the beginning of a long line of eye adaption.

what *I define as microevolution

(continued) You might assume that the proven cases of microevolution involve creating new genetic information, but they do not. They merely involve expressing genetic information in a different way (e.g. finch beaks) or disabling genes that have become disadvantageous (e.g. antibiotic-resistant bacteria). It is certainly proven that new genetic information and new body plans have come to exist over time (macroevolution), but natural selection cannot have caused those changes change.

In that case, there's no proof for half of what you call microevolution. What's proven is that random variations do occur in species and that the variations that are advantageous to the species are more likely to be passed on. That's what a define as microevolution. There's no proof that this process can produce ANY new genetic information, ANY new protein, ANY new celular machine or ANY new component of a body plan. In fact, there's strong proof that it can't produce any of those things.

Right, just like fixing bugs and writing new versions of software are the same thing. The driving force of microevolution, natural selection, simply takes the good features that already exist in a species and perfects them by eliminating versions of the species that have imperfect features. New features, however, cannot be created by natural selection because it doesn't even know about the features until they are fully functional.
Macroevolution- New features
Microevolution - Perfecting features

Yes and no.  Evolution is a fact and a theory, but when we talk about the fact of evolution we're not talking about the theory of evolution and vice versa.  The fact of evolution is the observable tendency of random mutations to introduce themselves in an organism's genome over generations.  The theory of evolution attempts to explain how that observable fact results in speciation and how we ended up with life as we see it today.  

The fact of evolution is not debatable.  The theory is.

Dismissed does not mean disproved. You are free to ignore it, and believe only that for which you have evidence.

I never said facts are a democracy, you are the one suggesting that the widely accepted facts (such as gravity) should be accepted on face value until proven otherwise. I am saying that if you want someone to accept something as fact, you have to prove it to them - just as how 2+2=4 is proven to children by giving them 2 pairs of things and asking them to count them.

If you want them to stop believing, then it is your responsibility to disprove the positive claim. If you don't care whether they believe or not then no, you have no responsibility to disprove the claim.

That is the point I am trying to make. The burden of proof is not (as you seem to suppose) on everyone else - only it is if you don't want to convince anyone of anything, but the moment you try to change someone else's mind, it's up to you to prove it.

Blaming theism for war is naive and misguided - after all, atheists have just as many excuses for killing each other as theists, ie as many as they can think of. I would posit that an entirely atheistic society would have as many wars (no more, no less) as an entirely theistic society, they would just make different excuses - the evidence so far seems to support this.

Again, you come back with an example that does not prove your point. The person claiming to be abducted by aliens has the burden of proof if they want to convince others of their case, but just as equally to convince the "abductee" that they weren't abducted by aliens, the burden of proof would lie on those trying to convince them they're wrong.

Anyone can claim anything - you don't have to believe them, it doesn't make them right. A claim is just that - a claim, not a fact.

You are starting your examples with assertions to the contrary - in other words starting by assuming your position is true and therefore the position being claimed must prove itself to you. That in itself was exactly what I was saying before - the burden of proof lies on the person trying to convince others to change their opinion on what is true.

This is the first time you've decided to separate types of belief, so how am I to know which specific definition you care about and which you don't?

Whether or not the claim is a positive or negative assertion is irrelevant - the claim that "Gravity isn't real" is still a claim, the burden of proof would still lie on the one making the claim.
You are obviously confusing blind faith (faith without reason) with faith (the belief in something of which you cannot be certain) - faith can be reasoning, eg scientists have faith in their tools.
The burden of proof continues to lie with the one trying to convince others of their point of view.

Yes, the burden lies on the claimant - but what is the claim? "there is no God" is as much a claim as "there is a God". There is a difference between refuting a claim and claiming the opposite.

I say "Just because" is not fine for an answer - as you point out, scientists don't say "Just because", they prove it. Theists don't say "Just because" either - they use evidence of history, experience, and the existence of natural order (science) - disputable things but tangible things too.

It's impossible to prove God's existence or non-existence by reason; we MUST wager that he exists or that he doesn't. If we wager he doesn't exist and are correct we loose nothing. If we wager he doesn't exist and are incorrect, we loose all. If we wager he exists and are incorrect, we lose nothing. If we wager he exists and are correct, we gain everything. The only way to win is to wager that God exists. It is therefore illogical to believe that God doesn't exist. - Pascal's Wager

The question posed, particularly the "who," is incorrectly phrased. What is the origin of the breastfeeding instinct, you ask? Well, millions of years ago, when the first mammals arose, groups of mammals with genes that gave them, for no particular reason, the urge to suckle upon nipples as babies, were more likely to survive than babies that had to be fed more forcefully. Those genes were passed on, and gradually, baby mammmals became more and more adept at feeding from breasts.
